newsitem.title: USA: NYSE said to set Sept 17 cutoff for options bids.
newsitem.headline: NYSE said to set Sept 17 cutoff for options bids.

text.p: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has set September 17 as the deadline for bids for its equity options business, industry sources said on Thursday.
"The New York Stock Exchange wants final proposals on their desk by (next) Tuesday," a source at the American Stock Exchange (AMEX) said.
But a New York Stock Exchange spokesman was unable to confirm whether that date was the deadline.

The four other U.S. options exchanges -- the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, the Pacific Stock Exchange and the AMEX -- have all expressed interest in the business, as has the New York Cotton Exchange.
As the deadline for final proposals draws near, speculation about which exchange would get the business increased a notch on Thursday, with the AMEX cited most commonly as the winner.
"I hear the NYSE has all but done a deal with the AMEX," one industry source said.
Another source said the AMEX had held or had scheduled a special meeting on the deal this week.
"It looks to me like a done deal," he said.
The NYSE spokesman said he could not comment, but an AMEX spokesman denied the speculation.
"We're submitting a proposal, we're very interested," an AMEX spokesman said. "But I couldn't say we're close to a deal."
On Wednesday, AMEX vice president of derivatives Joseph Stefanelli said in an interview with Reuters that the exchange would "very shortly" submit its proposal to the NYSE.
Stefanelli declined to say exactly when the proposal would be made or to disclose its financial terms.
He called the AMEX's bid "very realistic and very competitive."
Traders said speculation or not, the AMEX appeared to have the upper hand, especially because it is located just blocks from the NYSE in lower Manhattan.
"I think the deal will be done with us," the AMEX source said. "We're making a very competitive bid and people don't want to go from New York to, say, Chicago."

In the interview on Wednesday, Stefanelli said: "The most important factor is to disrupt the lives of the current membership as little as possible. We're looking at bringing their membership to trade on our floor."
